SnowDistribution: Icy paths and hillsides with very patchy snow cover. Cold clear conditions. Generally calm with only light winds.
Comment: Greater accumulations of snow, to lower levels, are expected into New Years Day across the North of Scotland.
WeatherInfluences: A North-Westerly airflow will bring increasing cloud cover overnight and through the day. Showery precipitation during the afternoon will fall as snow above 900 metres as the freezing level rises. Light West-North-Westerly winds will slowly increase moderate to fresh.
SnowStability: The very patchy snowpack will remain frozen and firm, and will be stable. The largest amounts of snow being on North to East aspects above 950 metres, particularly in sheltered gullies and hollows. Fresh accumulations of snow during the afternoon are not expected to be significant in quantity. Paths, hillsides and rocks will be icy underfoot. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry and bright with plenty of winter sunshine. Remaining very cold at all elevations, around minus 4 Celsius at 1000 metres around midday. Light winds from the East.
ObservedSnowStability: The very patchy snowpack continues to be frozen and firm, and is stable. The largest amounts of snow remain on North to East aspects above 950 metres, particularly in sheltered gullies and hollows. Paths, hillsides and rocks are icy underfoot. The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Sparse snow cover mostly bare ground. Icy paths and hillsides. Winds approx 10mph or less
Comment: Expanses of bullet hard water ice on some paths and hillsides. Any new windslab development expected later in the day.
WeatherInfluences: Dry, cold conditions overnight and for most of the morning followed by some light snow showers. Light Westerly winds becoming much stronger later.
SnowStability: The patchy old snowpack will be firm and stable. What remains lies mainly around coire rims, steep slopes and at the tops of gullies above 950 metres on North to East aspects. A general dusting of new snow above 900m by the end of the day. Any new windslab development will be thin, limited in extent and confined to steep North East to South East aspects above 1000m.  The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry and cold with light variable winds.
ObservedSnowStability: The sparse old snowpack is firm and stable. It lies mainly around coire rims, on steep upper slopes and at the tops of gullies above 950 metres on North to East aspects. The greatest extent lies around Coire Ardair. Snow cover on the Creag Meagaidh summit plateau is quite patchy.  The avalanche hazard is Low

SnowDistribution: Firm snow and icy watercourses. Good visibility.  Winds 10mph or less.
Comment: The firm snow continues to present serious consequences in the event of slips, trips or falls. Some snow forecast over the next few days although how much reaches Lochaber remains to be seen.
WeatherInfluences: Light winds overnight increase through the day to become strong West-South-Westerlies. Mainly dry with some precipitation in the afternoon falling as snow above 800 metres. The freezing level will rise through the period to around 900 metres.
SnowStability: The snowpack will remain firm and stable. Fresh snow accumulations are not expected to be significant. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: It was a dry, sunny day with light variable winds. Temperatures were below zero at all elevations.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack remains hard, icy and stable in all locations. Greatest deposits are on high North to East aspects. The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Limited patchy snow in specific places. Good visibility. Cold Northerly winds easing during the day.
Comment: Difficult underfoot conditions - Icy paths and ice glazed rocks. Old snow very firm.
WeatherInfluences: Dry throughout the period until late afternoon when some light snow is possible above 800 metres. Winds will steadily increase in strength to become gale force West-North-Westerlies.
SnowStability: The remaining snow will be firm and well bonded. Small patches will be found above 850 metres. Some larger areas will be encountered above 950 metres on North to East aspects, mainly around corrie rims and in gully tops. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A trace of overnight snow above 600 metres, followed by a dry and bright day. Winds were fresh easing to light, generally Northerly. -4 at 900 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: The remaining snow is well bonded with very firm surface layers. Patches are present above 850 metres. Larger areas can be found above 950 metres on North to East aspects, mostly around corrie rims and in gully tops.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Winds approx 10 - 20 mph fresh, cooling.  Icy paths and hillsides.  Increasingly good visibility during the day.
Comment: An Artic Maritime air mass will start to dominate from New Years Day. So expect frequent snow and hail showers and very strong North-Westerly winds with bitterly cold temperatures.
WeatherInfluences: Fresh North-Westerly winds backing Westerly and increasing to gale force during the afternoon. A mainly dry day is expected, with the possibility of light snow showers late afternoon. Variable freezing level.
SnowStability: Little change expected. The existing snowpack will remain hard with good stability in all locations. The greatest areas of snow will be confined to coire back walls, coire rims, and on high plateaus on North to East aspects above 950 metres.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Light North-Westerly winds. A very thin dusting of overnight snow. Freezing down to glen level.
ObservedSnowStability: The remaining snowpack is \'bullet\' hard with good stability in all locations. The greatest areas of snow are confined to coire back walls, coire rims, and on high plateaus on North to East aspects above 950 metres.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

SnowDistribution: Sparse snow cover mostly bare ground.  Cold clear conditions. Winds approx 10mph or less.
Comment: Some uncertainty in precipitation amounts for Wednesday. Northerly airflow is forecast to bring snow to lower levels from Thursday.
WeatherInfluences: After a dry night, precipitation will develop from late morning. This will fall as snow above around 900 metres with the freezing level rising to a similar level and westerly winds increasing in strength to become strong.
SnowStability: A thin covering of new snow will develop above 900 metres from late morning, this will mostly overlie bare ground. The few remaining old snow patches will be firm and stable. The avalanche hazard will be Low
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A cold clear dry day with very light wind.
ObservedSnowStability: The remaining snow is firm and stable. It lies mainly around coire rims, on steep upper slopes and at the tops of some gullies above 850 metres on North to East aspects. The greatest extent lies in the Northern Fannichs. There is insufficient snow to warrant issuing an avalanche hazard category.
